headline: Discovery of prehistoric tunnel in Rio Grande do Sul draws attention of scientists
context: Excavated amidst the stone walls and forest in the rural area of the municipality of Sant'Ana do Livramento, in Rio Grande do Sul, the tunnel appears to have been built by human hands and minds. However, palaeontologists point out that this rock formation, known as a palaeoburrow, may have been a shelter and habitat for gigantic animals that occupied the region at least 11 thousand years ago. Specimens of extinct fauna, such as the giant sloth, but which continue to fascinate and intrigue scientists.

“These large xenarthrans (mammals originating from South America), such as the giant sloth, had shapes that could reach up to five or six metres in height. They could be ungulates, these ancient and large relatives of armadillos, they could be giant armadillos. But we cannot rule out the possibility of it being some carnivore", says Ana Maria Ribeiro, palaeontologist at the Rio Grande do Sul Natural Sciences Museum, when considering what type of animal may have originated the prehistoric cave.

annotations.paragraph: The researcher is part of a multidisciplinary team that is investigating the palaeoburrow, currently located on the land of a winery in the region. The most recent scientific visit to the site was carried out earlier this year with the aim of better mapping the tunnel and collecting more traces of the presence of animals that passed through and lived in the space. Similar to the palaeoburrow in question, other structures have been mapped in Sant'Ana do Livramento and surrounding areas.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides details about the ongoing investigation and mapping of the palaeoburrow, which is directly related to the discovery.

annotations.paragraph: “The western border region (of Rio Grande do Sul), in terms of paleontological records, is well characterised by the discovery of many dinosaur footprints and trails here in the region,” says biologist and professor at the Universidade do Vale do Rio dos Sinos (UNISINOS) Renata Neto.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides context about the paleontological significance of the region, which is relevant to the discovery.

annotations.paragraph: In parts of Europe and North America, these are called palaeoburrows. Due to their geological formation history, they are uncommon in these regions of the world.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides comparative context about the rarity of palaeoburrows in other parts of the world, which is relevant to understanding the significance of the discovery.

annotations.paragraph: "These are areas affected by four glaciations in 600 thousand years, which acted as terrain levelers. Traces left by extinct fauna were consumed by the action of natural agents, if not by human activity", explains Heinrich Theodor Frank, professor at the Institute of Geosciences at the Federal University of Rio Grande do Sul (UFRGS).
annotations.reason: This paragraph explains why palaeoburrows are uncommon in certain regions, providing relevant geological context.

annotations.paragraph: In the Southern Hemisphere, palaeoburrows are much more frequent, especially in Brazil. In the state of Rio Grande do Sul alone, experts estimate that around a thousand structures like this have been mapped to date. The palaeoburrow in Sant'Ana do Livramento is considered the southernmost discovery in the country.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides relevant information about the frequency and significance of palaeoburrows in Brazil, particularly in the context of the discovery.

annotations.paragraph: As the guardian of this paleontological discovery, the winery from Rio Grande do Sul is now investing in the construction of a tourist trail on the property that will allow visitors to visit the prehistoric site. An experience that will combine wine tourism, history and conservation.
annotations.reason: The paragraph provides information about the development of a tourist trail related to the prehistoric site, which is relevant to the discovery.

annotations.paragraph: “This is the point of wine tourism, where people come here, taste the wine, and have the part of the history of the paleontological burrow at the same time. You leave satisfied with the history and the wine you tasted”, says Alex Machado, the wine tourism manager at the enterprise.
annotations.reason: The quote elaborates on the integration of wine tourism with the prehistoric site, adding context to the site's significance.
